description: From Middle English harvest, hervest, from Old English hærfest (“autumn, harvest-time; August”), from Proto-West Germanic *harbist, from Proto-Germanic *harbistaz (“harvest-time, autumn, fall”), from *harbaz, from Proto-Indo-European *kerp-.

entries.meaning: (UK, dialectal) The third season of the year; autumn; fall.
examples: Harvest is usually very damp and rainy.

entries.meaning: The season of gathering ripened crops; specifically, the time of reaping and gathering grain.
The process of gathering the ripened crop; harvesting.
The yield of harvesting, i.e., the gathered crops or fruits.
examples: This year's cotton harvest was great but the corn harvest was disastrous.

entries.meaning: (by extension) The product or result of any exertion or course of action; reward or consequences.
examples: the harvest of a quiet eye

entries.meaning: (paganism) A modern pagan ceremony held on or around the autumn equinox, which is in the harvesting season.

verbs.description: harvest (third-person singular simple present harvests, present participle harvesting, simple past and past participle harvested)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bring in a harvest; reap; glean.
(transitive, euphemistic) To kill for meat, slaughter.
(intransitive) To be occupied bringing in a harvest
examples: Harvesting is a stressing, thirsty occupation
The rising star harvested well-deserved acclaim, even an Oscar under 21
